org.jtrim.swing.concurrent

Class SwingTaskExecutor

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim.concurrent.DelegatedTaskExecutorService
      • org.jtrim.swing.concurrent.SwingTaskExecutor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutor, org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutorService

    public final class SwingTaskExecutor
extends org.jtrim.concurrent.DelegatedTaskExecutorService
    Defines a TaskExecutorService which executes submitted tasks on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. Submitted tasks are executed in the order they were submitted. Unlike TaskExecutorService implementations in general, SwingTaskExecutor instances does not need to be shutted down (although shutdown is still possible).

    In case the services provided by the TaskExecutor service are adequate, consider using the more efficient implementations returned by the static getSimpleExecutor or getStrictExecutor methods.

    A static instance can be retrieved by the getDefaultInstance method. The instance returned by this method can be used as a sensible default value.

    Thread safety

    Methods of this class are safely accessible from multiple threads concurrently.

    Synchronization transparency

    Method of this class are not synchronization transparent unless otherwise noted.
    See Also:
    getDefaultInstance(), getSimpleExecutor(boolean), getStrictExecutor(boolean)

    • Constructor Detail

      • SwingTaskExecutor

        public SwingTaskExecutor()
        Creates a new SwingTaskExecutor which will execute submitted tasks on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread.

        This constructor is equivalent to calling SwingTaskExecutor(true).

      • SwingTaskExecutor

        public SwingTaskExecutor(boolean alwaysInvokeLater)
        Creates a new SwingTaskExecutor which will execute submitted tasks on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread.
        Parameters:
        alwaysInvokeLater - if this argument is true, submitted tasks are never executed synchronously on the calling thread (i.e.: they are always submitted as SwingUtilities.invokeLater does it). In case this argument is false, tasks submitted from the AWT Event Dispatch Thread will be executed immediately on the calling thread (this may not always possible to execute tasks in the order they were submitted).

    • Method Detail

      • getDefaultInstance

        public static org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutorService getDefaultInstance()
        Returns a TaskExecutorService which executes tasks submitted to them on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. This method always returns the same TaskExecutorService instance and is intended to be used as a sensible default value when an executor is need which executes task on the EDT. The returned TaskExecutorService cannot be shutted down, attempting to do so will cause an unchecked exception to be thrown.
        Returns:
        a TaskExecutorService which executes tasks submitted to them on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. This method never returns null.

      • getSimpleExecutor

        public static org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutor getSimpleExecutor(boolean alwaysInvokeLater)
        Returns a TaskExecutor which executes tasks submitted to them on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. The returned executor does not necessarily executes tasks in the same order as the tasks were submitted. In case tasks needed to be executed in the same order as they were submitted to the executor: Use the getStrictExecutor(boolean) method.

        The returned executor is more efficient than an instance of SwingTaskExecutor.

        Parameters:
        alwaysInvokeLater - if this argument is true, submitted tasks are never executed synchronously on the calling thread (i.e.: they are always submitted as SwingUtilities.invokeLater does it). In case this argument is false, tasks submitted from the AWT Event Dispatch Thread will be executed immediately on the calling thread.
        Returns:
        a TaskExecutor which executes tasks submitted to them on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. This method never returns null.
        See Also:
        getStrictExecutor(boolean)

      • getStrictExecutor

        public static org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutor getStrictExecutor(boolean alwaysInvokeLater)
        Returns a TaskExecutor which executes tasks submitted to them on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. The returned executor executes tasks in the same order as the tasks were submitted. If you don't need to execute them in the same order, consider using the getSimpleExecutor(boolean) method.

        The returned executor is more efficient than an instance of SwingTaskExecutor.

        Parameters:
        alwaysInvokeLater - if this argument is true, submitted tasks are never executed synchronously on the calling thread (i.e.: they are always submitted as SwingUtilities.invokeLater does it). In case this argument is false, tasks submitted from the AWT Event Dispatch Thread will be executed immediately on the calling thread (this may not always possible to execute tasks in the order they were submitted).
        Returns:
        a TaskExecutor which executes tasks submitted to them on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. This method never returns null.
        See Also:
        getSimpleExecutor(boolean)

      • awaitTermination

        public void awaitTermination(org.jtrim.cancel.CancellationToken cancelToken)

        This method may not be called from the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. This is forbidden because it is very dead-lock prone: If a task was submitted to this executor, it could not complete because this method prevents any task to be executed on the EDT.

        Specified by:
        awaitTermination in interface org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutorService
        Overrides:
        awaitTermination in class org.jtrim.concurrent.DelegatedTaskExecutorService
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if the current calling thread is the AWT Event Dispatch Thread

      • tryAwaitTermination

        public boolean tryAwaitTermination(org.jtrim.cancel.CancellationToken cancelToken,
                          long timeout,
                          java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)

        This method may not be called from the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. This is forbidden because it is very dead-lock prone: If a task was submitted to this executor, it could not complete because this method prevents any task to be executed on the EDT.

        Specified by:
        tryAwaitTermination in interface org.jtrim.concurrent.TaskExecutorService
        Overrides:
        tryAwaitTermination in class org.jtrim.concurrent.DelegatedTaskExecutorService
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if the current calling thread is the AWT Event Dispatch Thread
